messages.text:
Here’s a clean Slack report draft based on what you wrote. I’ll keep it crisp but complete, and I’ll fix the messy parts you had (because yeah, your raw notes were pretty chaotic).

*Weekly Update / Change Report — Slack OAuth Refactor*
*What changed*
• Major refactor: Slack OAuth no longer uses Composio.
• OAuth flow has been moved into the Slack adapter, aligning with our existing source-adapter architecture.
*Why*
• We needed to filter webhook messages to only process events from integrations whose authenticating user is actually a member of the relevant Slack channel.
• To do that, we must store the Slack _user ID_ of the person who authenticated the connection.
• With Composio bot-token auth:
    ◦ We couldn’t reliably fetch the authenticating user’s identity.
    ◦ Composio doesn’t support mixed scopes (user + bot) in a single auth config.
    ◦ I tried multiple approaches to work around this limitation, but none were viable.
*Solution*
• Implemented Slack OAuth flow directly (manual OAuth), independent of Composio.
• Added storage of the authenticating Slack user ID during the OAuth process.
• Relocated all OAuth logic into the Slack adapter (where it belongs given our architecture).
*Impact*
• Behavior remains the same for users: everything works like before.
• Internally, Slack auth is now fully owned by us, removing Composio constraints.
• Enables correct channel-membership filtering for webhook events.
*Status*
• Refactor completed.
• Implementation covered with tests and verified end-to-end.
*Next steps / follow-ups*
• Monitor for any edge cases in Slack OAuth (token refresh, reinstall flow).
• Consider documenting adapter-owned OAuth as standard for other sources if they hit similar mixed-scope limitations.
If you want this to be _even tighter_ for Slack (like 5–6 lines max), tell me the target format/style in your team channel and I’ll compress it. But this version is solid and won’t get you follow-up questions.

Here’s a clean Slack report draft based on what you wrote. I’ll keep it crisp but complete, and I’ll fix the messy parts you had (because yeah, your raw notes were pretty chaotic).

*Weekly Update / Change Report — Slack OAuth Refactor*
*What changed*
• Major refactor: Slack OAuth no longer uses Composio.
• OAuth flow has been moved into the Slack adapter, aligning with our existing source-adapter architecture.
*Why*
• We needed to filter webhook messages to only process events from integrations whose authenticating user is actually a member of the relevant Slack channel.
• To do that, we must store the Slack _user ID_ of the person who authenticated the connection.
• With Composio bot-token auth:
    ◦ We couldn’t reliably fetch the authenticating user’s identity.
    ◦ Composio doesn’t support mixed scopes (user + bot) in a single auth config.
    ◦ I tried multiple approaches to work around this limitation, but none were viable.
*Solution*
• Implemented Slack OAuth flow directly (manual OAuth), independent of Composio.
• Added storage of the authenticating Slack user ID during the OAuth process.
• Relocated all OAuth logic into the Slack adapter (where it belongs given our architecture).
*Impact*
• Behavior remains the same for users: everything works like before.
• Internally, Slack auth is now fully owned by us, removing Composio constraints.
• Enables correct channel-membership filtering for webhook events.
*Status*
• Refactor completed.
• Implementation covered with tests and verified end-to-end.
*Next steps / follow-ups*
• Monitor for any edge cases in Slack OAuth (token refresh, reinstall flow).
• Consider documenting adapter-owned OAuth as standard for other sources if they hit similar mixed-scope limitations.
If you want this to be _even tighter_ for Slack (like 5–6 lines max), tell me the target format/style in your team channel and I’ll compress it. But this version is solid and won’t get you follow-up questions.

messages.text:
فرزین جان روی لوکال من نمیتونم با
```<http://localhost:3000/v1/auth/google>```
توی بک اند لاگین بشم. یعنی جیمیل خطای میسمچ یوآرال میده:
```
Error 400: redirect_uri_mismatch
Request details: redirect_uri=<http://localhost:3000/v1/auth/callback/google> flowName=GeneralOAuthFlow```

elements.text: فرزین جان روی لوکال من نمیتونم با
توی بک اند لاگین بشم. یعنی جیمیل خطای میسمچ یوآرال میده:

messages.text:
این مکالمه ای که داشتید تبدیل به تسک میتونه بشه.


Asghar reported an UNRESOLVED technical blocker preventing local development environment from running. He tested multiple APP_DOMAIN configurations (localhost:3000, localhost) without success. Farzin provided troubleshooting guidance (use APP_DOMAIN=localhost, check getAppUrl method in config service, APP_URL takes precedence over APP_DOMAIN) but issue remains unresolved after 27 minutes of back-and-forth. Asghar requested a huddle to resolve it. This is blocking local development work. Assigning to Farzin as he has infrastructure/backend expertise and was actively troubleshooting. Priority 2 (High) as it's blocking Asghar's ability to work locally but not affecting production. Moderate confidence (65) because root cause isn't yet identified - they need the proposed huddle to diagnose further.

elements.text:
این مکالمه ای که داشتید تبدیل به تسک میتونه بشه.


Asghar reported an UNRESOLVED technical blocker preventing local development environment from running. He tested multiple APP_DOMAIN configurations (localhost:3000, localhost) without success. Farzin provided troubleshooting guidance (use APP_DOMAIN=localhost, check getAppUrl method in config service, APP_URL takes precedence over APP_DOMAIN) but issue remains unresolved after 27 minutes of back-and-forth. Asghar requested a huddle to resolve it. This is blocking local development work. Assigning to Farzin as he has infrastructure/backend expertise and was actively troubleshooting. Priority 2 (High) as it's blocking Asghar's ability to work locally but not affecting production. Moderate confidence (65) because root cause isn't yet identified - they need the proposed huddle to diagnose further.

attachments.fallback: How to Choose The Best Databases for RAG: Developer's Guide
attachments.text: Selecting the right database is fundamental for building high-performing RAG applications. This guide explores essential criteria, compares database types (vector-native vs. extended traditional DBs), and provides insights to help developers and ML engineers choose the optimal solution for vector search, scalability, and low-latency retrieval.
attachments.title: How to Choose The Best Databases for RAG: Developer's Guide

messages.text: ۵ بنظرم خوبه
<@U09FLV6BPQB>
are
5 khube

*US-100: Core Infrastructure Update*
*Technical Tasks:*
• Update Database Schema
• Decouple PM Module for Independent Operation
• Extract Integrations into a Standalone Module
• Implement Event-Emitter Notifications for PM and Integration Modules

*US-101: Cross-Platform Context Onboarding*
*Technical Tasks:*
1. Add core agent and agentic loop
2. Implement project brief agent (Gather data from all connected sources to create the project brief)

*US-102: Process Incoming Event*
1. Add embedding module as a standalone service (Use Weaviate as Vector db and , Voyage as embedding Model)
    a. Design database schema: embedding, metadata
    b. Decide on RAG strategies per integration source (chunking, multiple similar query embedding, LLM re-ranking, etc)
2. Add messages to proper clusters / create new cluster

*US-103: Smart Context Retrieval for Action Suggestions*
*Technical Tasks:*
1. Do hybrid search to find most similar clusters
	•		2.	Score and Re-rank the search results

elements.text: Decouple PM Module for Independent Operation
Extract Integrations into a Standalone Module
Implement Event-Emitter Notifications for PM and Integration Modules
Add core agent and agentic loop
Implement project brief agent (Gather data from all connected sources to create the project brief)
Add embedding module as a standalone service (Use Weaviate as Vector db and , Voyage as embedding Model)
Decide on RAG strategies per integration source (chunking, multiple similar query embedding, LLM re-ranking, etc)
Add messages to proper clusters / create new cluster
US-103: Smart Context Retrieval for Action Suggestions
Do hybrid search to find most similar clusters
•		2.	Score and Re-rank the search results

messages.text:
*Update: Topic Detection R&D Progress*
Built a working prototype for automatic topic detection using Slack messages + RAG + AI Agent.
*What I tried:*
• Started with semantic search only → poor results
• Added agentic loop with tool-calling → significantly better
• Iterated heavily on context gathering, tool design, and system prompts
*Current state:*
• Working solution with 13 specialized tools
• Handles Persian + English messages
• Thread-aware categorization
• Duplicate topic prevention with fuzzy matching
*Next steps:*
• Further tuning on edge cases
• Need a feedback loop for learning from corrections
• More testing before production-ready
Documentation + test project available if anyone wants to dig in.


and this is the repo: <https://github.com/ho3einmolavi/slack-topic-detector-ai>

:wrench: Gmail Webhook Deduplication
Added deduplication logic for Gmail integration events. The system now checks if an email (by messageId) has already been processed before creating a new IntegrationEvent.
What changed:
• Before creating events, we query existing events by userIntegrationId + externalId (Gmail messageId)
• Duplicate emails are skipped with logging
• Prevents duplicate events when Gmail sends the same notification multiple times
Result: No more duplicate integration events for the same email :tada:

elements.text:
Gmail Webhook Deduplication
Added deduplication logic for Gmail integration events. The system now checks if an email (by messageId) has already been processed before creating a new IntegrationEvent.
What changed:
Before creating events, we query existing events by userIntegrationId + externalId (Gmail messageId)
Duplicate emails are skipped with logging
Prevents duplicate events when Gmail sends the same notification multiple times
Result: No more duplicate integration events for the same email

messages.text:
Gmail webhook deduplication fix

Fixed Gmail webhook deduplication by using RFC Message-ID instead of Gmail's internal message ID.

Problem:
- Gmail webhooks were creating duplicate `IntegrationEvent` records for the same email
- The deduplication logic was using Gmail's internal message ID, which can change or be inconsistent

Solution:
- Updated `GmailAdapterService` to extract the RFC Message-ID from email headers when fetching messages
- Now using RFC Message-ID as `externalId` for deduplication (with fallback to Gmail message ID if unavailable)
- RFC Message-ID is a standard email header that uniquely identifies emails across systems

Changes:
- `fetchMessagesByIds()` now extracts RFC Message-ID from headers when fetching with `format: 'full'`
- `processWebhook()` uses `rfcMessageId` as `externalId` (preferred) with fallback to `messageId`
- Both IDs are stored in metadata for reference

elements.text:
Gmail webhook deduplication fix

Fixed Gmail webhook deduplication by using RFC Message-ID instead of Gmail's internal message ID.

Problem:
- Gmail webhooks were creating duplicate `IntegrationEvent` records for the same email
- The deduplication logic was using Gmail's internal message ID, which can change or be inconsistent

Solution:
- Updated `GmailAdapterService` to extract the RFC Message-ID from email headers when fetching messages
- Now using RFC Message-ID as `externalId` for deduplication (with fallback to Gmail message ID if unavailable)
- RFC Message-ID is a standard email header that uniquely identifies emails across systems

Changes:
- `fetchMessagesByIds()` now extracts RFC Message-ID from headers when fetching with `format: 'full'`
- `processWebhook()` uses `rfcMessageId` as `externalId` (preferred) with fallback to `messageId`
- Both IDs are stored in metadata for reference
